Headline: Helping businesses grow organically through SEO, Social Media & Content Marketing | WordPress Website Creator | 7+ yrs driving visibility & engagement that converts
Comment:
Dilip Kumar

This is such a solid take! 

The whole "Uber of Healthcare" narrative oversimplifies a deeply complex system. 

Healthcare isn't just about transactions; it's about trust, continuity, and outcomes.

Tech can absolutely help, but not in the way most startups imagine‚Äîslapping AI on everything and calling it "disruption" isn‚Äôt the answer. 

Instead, the real impact comes from augmenting the system: improving diagnostics, streamlining supply chains, ensuring medicine authenticity, and empowering frontline workers.

It‚Äôs refreshing to see a take that focuses on first principles rather than just chasing scale. 

The biggest wins in healthcare won‚Äôt come from the flashiest tech but from solving real, foundational problems.

Headline: Doctor, Internal Medicine
Comment:
Healthcare management is a multifaceted field that requires a blend of strategic decision-making, human empathy, regulatory compliance, and real-time problem-solving. It involves coordinating medical professionals, managing resources, ensuring patient safety, and navigating complex healthcare policies‚Äîall while maintaining a patient-centered approach. While AI tools can enhance efficiency by analyzing data and automating administrative tasks, they lack the nuanced judgment, ethical reasoning, and interpersonal skills necessary for effective leadership. The ability to address unforeseen challenges, mediate conflicts, and make holistic decisions based on both data and human factors ensures that healthcare management remains an indispensable human-driven profession. 
Thank you for pointing that out sir! üëçüèΩüòä Dilip Kumar

Headline: I Help High-Performers Become the Person Their 2026 Life Requires | Premium 1:1 Coaching | Jump in for bigger life which is truly yours!
Comment:
Finally, a take that doesn‚Äôt fall for the ‚ÄúAI will save the world‚Äù fantasy.

Too many startups believe better UI + AI chatbot = healthcare revolution. But healthcare isn‚Äôt a checkout cart‚Äîit‚Äôs a life-and-death relationship.

Biggest takeaway? Tech should augment, not replace.

- AI can assist doctors, but it won‚Äôt replace experience and trust.
- A sleek app won‚Äôt fix supply chain chaos or fake medicine issues.
- Scaling care isn‚Äôt about matching patients to doctors‚Äîit‚Äôs about ensuring follow-up, outcomes, and real impact.

If you‚Äôre serious about ‚Äúfixing‚Äù healthcare, stop chasing disruption hype and start solving real problems.

Headline: AI Architect| Strategist | Generative AI| Agentic AI | Digital Transformation
Comment: I get it. Every entrepreneur wants to build the ‚ÄòUber of Healthcare.‚Äô But unlike booking a ride, healthcare is personal, complex, and needs constant care. If you‚Äôre serious about making a difference, focus on augmenting existing systems with tech that enhances doctor-patient relationships and improves outcomes, not just on scaling for scale‚Äôs sake.

Headline: Product @knowledgecity| Product Manager | Build Products across industries | , 3.5x Growth, 7x ROI | GTM, AI, Growth Strategy | B2B + B2C | India & US
Comment:
I second your thoughts..
We don‚Äôt need to disrupt healthcare, but to transform it.
Make it accessible to everyone, make it efficient and portable (where one patient can move to another facility without carrying a big pile of records, just like EHR/FHIR in US) and most importantly help frontline workers in rapid diagnosis.
The truth is, we have the basic infrastructure required to accomplish all these things, but the people who can make it happen are not so willing to make it happen.
Example -
We already have Aadhar in place, equavelant to SSN in US, all we need to create a centralised system where every detail, every visit, every hospitalisation along with diagnoses and treatment gets updated in the real-time , making it easy to access by healthcare professionals at patient visit.
India has a very large talent pool and most of it is busy in job hunt whereas we are lagging behind in AI innovation, why not using it to become an AI powerhouse?
Which can transform healthcare, environment and whatnot!

Headline: Head- Strategic Partnerships @ apna | Ex-Gov of India | Ex-Uber | Strategy & BizOps, Growth
Comment:
Everyone wants to build the ‚ÄòUber of Healthcare,‚Äô but forget that in Uber, the worst-case scenario is a delayed ride. In healthcare, it‚Äôs a misdiagnosed disease. The stakes aren‚Äôt just higher‚Äîthey‚Äôre life and death.

Tech isn‚Äôt a magic pill; it‚Äôs a scalpel. Used right, it can make precision cuts to solve real bottlenecks; supply chains, diagnostics, access. Used wrong, it just adds another flashy app to an already broken system.

The real challenge? Not disruption, but integration. Not replacing doctors, but empowering them. Not chasing scale, but fixing what‚Äôs fundamentally broken. That‚Äôs where the real billion-dollar opportunities lie.

Dilip, thanks for sharing your point of view! ‚ú®

Headline: Biohacking Coach | Researcher | Functional & Clinical Nutritionist | TEDx Speaker
Comment:
I couldn‚Äôt agree more! Healthcare, especially when it comes to optimizing functional health, isn‚Äôt a one-size-fits-all problem. Even if we set aside the absolute need for empathy in wellness transactions, the simple fact that we are all bio-individuals means no two imbalances are identical.

ML &AI are not replacements for human expertise but critical tools in advancing research, enabling deeper insights from biodata. These technologies are essential for identifying patterns & forming the backbone of personalized interventions.
This is exactly where we are focused‚Äîdeveloping biodata-driven solutions that integrate 100% clean health supplementation and precision nutrition.

Headline: Co-founder at Tequity | 0-1 Product Designer
Comment:
UI alone won‚Äôt fix the lack of infrastructure or disrupt chronic diseases. But a well-designed user experience‚Äîone that aligns with users' digital learning curve and mental model‚Äîcan make health-tech advancements truly scalable, usable, and impactful.

UX in digital healthcare isn‚Äôt an afterthought; it‚Äôs the difference between adoption and abandonment. There‚Äôs a reason WhatsApp is ubiquitous‚Äîit works for people, not against them. We need healthcare solutions that do the same‚Äîsolutions that adapt to users, not ones that force users to adapt.¬†‚ú®

Comment: Very informative, Tech alone won‚Äôt fix Indian healthcare, where doctor shortages (1:1,511), poor rural access (600M people), and 20% counterfeit drugs persist. Unlike e-commerce, healthcare needs trust, continuity, and affordability not just AI chatbots or doctor-matching apps. The real opportunity is in augmenting care- scaling AI-assisted frontline workers, securing drug supply chains, and improving patient outcomes. Disruption won‚Äôt work, but smart, systemic upgrades will.

Headline: Founder at JoiningHands | Family Constellation & Regression Therapist | Building a supportive community for healing & self-discovery
Comment:
I have a question: When we say fix it! We presume it‚Äôs broken. 

What if we see the world as not broken but as something that‚Äôs evolving. 

When we see it as broken we reject it! If you break a bone, see the Dr. If it breaks twice, increase calcium and get healthier. 

If it breaks thrice, then go to a Therapist to understand what you need to do in your frequency. 

It‚Äôs evolution, healthcare needs to evolve to cover all aspects of health.
